comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I was not sure what "degaussing" was. De-magnetising ships so they do not attract mines. Also I am not too sure this is Bradleys Head. It looks more like Chowder Bay (Clifton Gardens).

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I agree,  I am dubious that this is Bradleys Head.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Hmm - it WAS at Bradley's Head. There is a WRAN's wonderful personal description of the place and operations during WW2 here (two pages) - www.navyhistory.org.au/home-home-on-the-range-degaussing/ . Including this -
"The Degaussing Range (commonly known as the DG Range), attached to HMAS Kuttabul, was a two-storeyed timber building smothered in camouflage, which made it stand out like a beacon (I thought), and situated over the water’s edge at Bradley’s Head." . . . . ....."These days, there is only a small oblong brick structure remaining."

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: And, how is this for armchair archaeology? - I think these are the post holes still visible on the rocks on the east side of Bradley's Head, near a sandy beach - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
Degaussing was also used for televisions in removing any built up magnetic fields on the screen.
We don't have the problem now with flat screens.

They must have been storing TVs in there??  lol ;-)
